An absent-minded admin leaked half their RSA private key digits online. Can you exploit this slip to decrypt the intercepted message? Here it is: 807532631729924432245907860420190833121533881387719605906959424253586553557420217716496620792531854633393679620164626033648137047896256076402898440426221

The flag format is flag{...}
n=7097315010019068514921823643842253189500791367587746518634775916782005828274815014038908609864045673134392565625629365163127489189041788122385516825918509, e=10289676804365076174848944360468314956060098816629795269897227012968595448960495900042678759973141660896289857541657416002391480688058550703698564148887, partial_p=12169990325320865178

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{usq07gon}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 807532631729924432245907860420190833121533881387719605906959424253586553557420217716496620792531854633393679620164626033648137047896256076402898440426221
vulnerability: partial key exposure
hint: A partial exposure of a prime number's bits can significantly weaken RSA security. Look into lattice-based techniques like Coppersmith's attack.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=7097315010019068514921823643842253189500791367587746518634775916782005828274815014038908609864045673134392565625629365163127489189041788122385516825918509, e=10289676804365076174848944360468314956060098816629795269897227012968595448960495900042678759973141660896289857541657416002391480688058550703698564148887, partial_p=12169990325320865178
extra_info: p=76392267390710718398862855436444649813076167743574719725818390493116171503931, q=92906196562010939045342996263205233199904782153184307224782631008472668109239, Ï†(n)=7097315010019068514921823643842253189500791367587746518634775916782005828274645715574955888206601467282692915742616384213230730162091187100883927986305340
